title: Rear Mount Bracket for Eyetecs Fan

description.text:
I love Eytecs design for a fan thing:160252 however I wasnt sold on the way he mounted it to the printer.. it blocks the view of the nozzle, the fan opening on the bracket was square and not round like the fan, it didn't quite snap on and it seemed to me like it sits a little high as well.
I made this bracket to mount the nozzle do the back of the extruder and so far I think it works great! you get a clear view of the extruder and the fan blows the filament and not the tip of the extruder, enjoy!

In order to mount this:
mount my bracket first and position it where it needs to go,
after its in place attach the fan,
lastly mount the fan itself and hide wiring.
I don't think it has room to snap on fully assambled so it needs to be done in the 3 steps above

I converted my Air Wolf 3D XL to a dual extruder machine way back in March. I thought I could sell conversion kits, but I have too many other things going on in my life so I decided to share it with everyone. The design of the carriage is more compact than the original since the extruders are remotely feed so you get the same build width in the X direction and a little bit more in the Z. The Plexiglass (5mm) 1/2 enclosure was how I mounted the spools and extruders, but you can do that however you want.
Enjoy.
This is still a work in progress because the 8mm hobbed bolt drive is too small of a diameter to work effectively with a tube type system. I'll eventually convert my extruders to a bowden style setup and update my firmware with the new ratios.
It works with the smaller extruder drive, but I have to limit my retractions to keep the drive from stripping the filament. The penalty for that is excessive ooze from the inactive nozzle.

This is a pop out / pop in replacement. You don't have to take apart much, just the X axis belt. I did make a video with my GoPro and some day I'll get around to editing it so I can upload it to You Tube.
I've included all of the parts I printed to do the conversion. You'll also need some random screws, nuts, washers etc. You'll need another extruder, but if you have an Air Wolf 3D XL you'll have those files already. I got almost everything I needed at Home Depot and Ace Hardware, but I had to buy the bearings for the extruder from Amazon. The PTFE tubes 2nd extruder motor and hot end I was able to get from Air Wolf directly since I live close to their shop in Costa Mesa, CA.
Leveling the nozzles was accomplished using paper shims when mounting the Budaschnozzles to the mounting bracket.

These are some game tokens I'm making for a friend that have embedded RFID tags in the print.  
This is the same technology "Skylander" toys use except they have a 2 part plastic base that they put an RFID sticker in.

There is a sacrificial coin in the back that at a certain point in the build I pause the print so I have easy access to the cavity to place the RFID tag ~ .25mm thickness so the cavity is 2 layers tall.  I resume the print after the tag is in place and any ooze while paused is on the sacrificial coin in the back.  It "primes" the nozzle when it finishes the layer, then moves back to the token covering the RFID tag and finished the game piece.

An earth friendly alternative to k-cups

Items needed Acid brush (hardware store in plumbing)
DMC (fiberglass supplies store)
300 mesh stainless screen (Metal Supermarket, http://www.metalsupermarkets.com/)
4 printed parts. Cup, lid top and bottom ring.
gloves (DMC will strip all the oils out of your skin)
Safety gear (eyes, face,.lungs and toes,..) Print the parts, push bottom ring to bottom of cup, use an acid brush + liberal amounts of DMC to solvent weld bottom ring into place. Let harden for an hour.
meanwhile using the top ring as a template draw out a pattern then cut some 300 mesh screen to slightly under the OD of the top ring. Screen should fit in the bottom of the k-cup being held up by the bottom ring. Once you have a good fit, slip in the top ring. If needed use some DMC to Sol-Weld the top ring in place sandwiching the mesh between the two rings.

This is a Han Solo IPhone 6 case I made in Sketchup using Hangsta's case and Gianteye's Han Solo. I moved the arms a little bit down so that they won't break as easily. Update: I separated the case into two parts so that you don't have to use supports. Update: I added tolerances to the pieces so that they could fit together easier. I also split the separated model into two separate stl's. Update: I updated the designs so that they will fit with my blank 3D Separable iPhone 6 Case. You can now also pick out a different outside piece style. Update: I added a .3 mm tolerance as well.

• Print both pieces (the IS and OS) or print the full case with supports.
  • Print the inside piece (IS) depending on how much tolerance you want: 0.1mm, 0.2mm, or 0.5mm tolerance. They files are labeled (disregard this step if you have printed the full case).
  • Put the two pieces together so that Han Solo is on the outside (disregard this step also if you have printed the full case).
  • Put your phone in and swag on in intergalactic peace!

This is a customizable curve generator which can generate up to 5 different types of curves.
The Rhodonea (Rose) Curve, Epicycloid, Epitrochoid, Hypocycloid and Hypotrochoid curves can be generated with varying parameters.

UPDATE: Now supports up to 5 different types of curves. See updated instructions below for more information. I have also removed the extrusion option since openscad doesn't support rotate_extrude correctly. This script will generate an artistic rendering of a mathematical curve. It was originally a generator for the Rhodonea (Rose) Curve, but I've now added support for 4 more curve types.
Here are the equations used for each one of those curves :
Rhodonea curve : x=cos(a/bt)sin(t); y=cos(a/bt)cos(t)
Epicycloid : x=(a+b)cos(t)-bcos(((a/b)+1)t); y=(a+b)sin(t)-bsin(((a/b)+1)t)
Epitrochoid : x=(a+b)cos(t)-ccos(((a/b)+1)t); y=(a+b)sin(t)-csin(((a/b)+1)t)
Hypocycloid : x=(a-b)cos(t)+bcos(((a/b)-1)t); y=(a-b)sin(t)-bsin(((a/b)-1)t)
Hypotrochoid: x=(a-b)cos(t)+ccos(((a/b)-1)t); y=(a-b)sin(t)-csin(((a/b)-1)t)
(See also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rose_%28mathematics%29 ) You can set the 'a, 'b', and 'c' parameters to affect the look of the curve (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rose-rhodonea-curve-7x9-chart-improved.svg for example).
You can define how many points you want to be used to draw the result (higher gives better results, but takes longer to generate the STL). You can also control the thickness and height of the curve. The rose radius will set the radius of the petals. This will basically mean that the rose should fit in a circle with that radius. Experiment, create and enjoy!

title: A chip holder for reseting the Da Vinci 1.0 filament chip using an Arduino

description.text:
If you are using Non-XYZ filament in your Da Vinci 1.0, you are probably resetting the filament-counter-chip in the XYZ cartridges (as I am doing). So you have to attach three leads to the chip (and attach them to your Arduino). This is a bit of a pain, so I built myself a chip holder. It consists of a base with three 24 gage wires looped through holes in the base (and twisted to stay) that the chip fits on top of. The second piece is a "clamp" that slides over the back of base to hold the chip down against the three wires looped into the base. Each of the three 24 gage wires are then inserted into the proper pin-outs on the Arduino board. Tiny raised letters on the chip-holder's base remind you where to insert the leads: "G" for ground, "5V" for 5V and "7" for digital pin-out 7. If you want to find out how to use the Arduino board and get the Arduino "sketch" (program) that performs the resetting, here is the URL:
http://voltivo.com/blog/da-vinci-reset-eeprom If you have not bought an Arduino board yet, consider getting a Arduino Mini and using this other very slick thingaverse creation (by fr33 3n3rgy) that combines the Arduino Mini board and the contacts right into a module that plugs onto the bottom of the XYZ cartridge. You don't even have to take the chip out the cartridge case. Here is the URL:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:302209

Print the two parts. File the parts as shown in the picture in the gallery. The first couple of layers always bulge outward and these bulges must be filed off where fit is important. Also, inside corners always tend to be a bit rounded and need a filing to square them off. You'll need three 6-8 inch lengths of bare, 24 gauge solid copper wire. (I think 22 gauge will work as well - as long as it fits into the Arduino pin-out connectors.) Loop each wire though a pair of holes in the base and twist (on the bottom) to hold them in place. The left and right leads should extend straight down. But the center lead must be bent towards the front so that it is out of the way of the slide-on clamp. Take your filament chip out of the cartridge and place it on the top of the holder-base. Be sure to place the chip so the painted "corner-cut" lines up with the base's corner-cut. Slip the sliding clamp on from the back of the base to hold down the chip. Follow the instructions here:
http://voltivo.com/blog/da-vinci-reset-eeprom
... for doing the reset.

title: Dual E3D bowden coldend. With one (50mm) fan to rule/cool them all!

description.text:
I updated this design and it can be found here Wish/specs/feature list:
  • Easy to access both hotends
  • Nozzles fit close together (24mm nozzle to nozzle)
  • Replaces the noisy E3D fan(s) with a single 50mm fan
  • Fan should also cool the print
  • I like "fully" enclosed hotends
  • Tried to limit angles to 40 degrees so printing without support should be possible
  • For Prusa i3 or any printer that has the x-carriage bars arranged vertically
  • Requires a total of 4 m3 bolts and nuts for:
    the hinge(20mm), lock(10-20mm) and fan(~15mm) and 2 m4(20-25mm?) bolts and nuts for fastening to x-carriage.
    • Update: I've edited the door, made it shorter and removed the grill as it is unnecessary and only hinders airflow anyway. Added it as a separate file. Update2: I've created a version for E3D v5's I design all holes 0.25mm bigger so it fits a screw right away, your results may vary. Please message me if you run into issues. The hotend fits very tight. Accompanying story:
    I've been running with my self made bowden coldend which holds a single E3D v6 hotend, a servomotor for a z-probe and a blower fan cooling the print. I am planning to go for a dual E3D bowden setup so it is time to design a new coldend. This time I wanted easier access to the hotend, have a better visual of the print as my current one has a fan shroud at the front cooling the print. I'm thinking whether to keep the z-probe servo as I had issues with it oscillating. I've already ditched the bed leveling before printing as it's usually quite easy to align the bed so I might as well ditch the whole servo.

title: Arm Extension Kits for DJI Frames

description.text:
This kit upgrades ANY multirotor that uses the DJI-style arms. It is a drop-in swap for the stock arms and you’ll notice many improvements. Specifically, the kit:
  • Allows you to install ANY length or diameter arms. The kits are available for 8,10,12 and 16mm CF tubing.
  • Can use ANY motor – even large, low KV pancake motors.
  • Can mount ANY size propeller, simply by varying the arm length.
  • Stabilizes your multirotors – Better aerial photography!
  • Lightens your quad (the kit is less than 100g), which increases your flight time significantly.
  • Is stiffer than the stock DJI arms.
  • Is tougher than the stock arms.
  • Is cheaper & easier to repair after “gravity-related incidents” than stock DJI arms.

Here is what you’ll need:
  • Arm adapters
  • Motor mounts
  • Carbon Fiber tube
  • M4 x 20mm screws (4 for [email protected] Home Depot)
  • M4 Lock Nuts (the one with the nylon bushing), (4 for $0.64 @ Home Depot)
    Here’s how to upgrade your multirotor.
  • Remove the propellers.
  • Unplug the ESCs.
  • Remove the two bottom screws from each of the arms.
  • Remove the four top screws from each arm and set it aside. Repeat on all arms.
  • Cut your carbon tubes to the desired length.
  • Insert the M4 screw and nuts into the arm adapters and motor mounts but don’t torque them down yet.
  • Slip fit the arm adapters and motor mounts onto the tubes. They will be snug.
  • Tighten the arm adapter screw until you cannot turn the tube. DO NOT OVERTIGHTEN!!! It just needs to be snug. There is NO rotational stress on this part so PLEASE don’t go crazy with tightening this screw. Nothing good will come of it. You’ll either crush the carbon tube or break the motor mount. There is a wide variation in CF tube dimensions but the gap is wide enough to accommodate them all. Please do NOT tighten the screw until the gap is closed. If you cannot spin the arm adapter, then it is tight enough.
  • Slip on the motor mount but don’t tighten it yet.
  • Lay the arm on a flat surface to make sure the motor mount is level with the top of the arm adapter. Once it is, snug the screw until the mount will not turn. Again, please DO NOT OVERTIGHTEN. Snug is good. (Too tight and you’ll get pissed at yourself for stripping or breaking something. Just avoid the pain and don’t gorilla-tighten the screws…).
  • Install the arm into your frame. Use the original SHORT screws on the top and they will cut their own threads into the ABS and it will act like a lock nut. In almost 120 hours of flying these I have NEVER had a screw back out of the ABS. Again, just snug the screws up and DO NOT OVERTIGHTEN. Yes, you are strong and I am SURE you can strip the plastic, but please don’t do it. Snug is good.
  • Use original LONG screws on the bottom two legs. The long screws will add additional strength to the legs and, like the top screws, will never back out or vibrate loose. Snug is your friend. Over-tightening will end up something broken or stripped.
  • As you install each arm, zip tie your ESC to the arm to keep it from flopping around and stressing the soldered joints.
  • Once all the arms are mounted, double check that the motor mounts are still perfectly level. This is critical on all CF-armed multirotors. Close is not good enough. If they are not nearly perfect then your yaw control will suffer and it will not give you a stable hover.
  • Mount the motors. The mounts accommodate everything from 18mm to 50mm motors. Cheap insurance: Use Loctite on the motor mounting screws. (I have not tried every single motor on the market but have tried KDE Direct, Tiger, Multistar, Sunnysky and DJI and they all mount while the motor mount is attached to the CF arm. If you have a motor that cannot mount with the tube installed it is no big deal and usually happens with the 16mm tubes and a motor with a narrow mount. Just slide off the motor mount, install the motor, re-install the motor mount and re-level it. Easy). (Pictured is the Sunnysky “Angel” line which has a tiny mounting screw pattern.)
  • TIP: The motor mounts have a provision to allow in-tubing wiring. Aesthetically, this is nice and I’ve designed in a “bumper” on the end to run your wires through and protect them. From a practical point of view it is not optimal. Thru-tubing wiring requires more wire, which can add up to 100g of unnecessary weight. It is also harder to maintain and inspect. Finally, it is MUCH more difficult to repair if you have a “gravity-related incident”. With outside wiring zip tied to the arms, you simply unplug everything, replace the broken part (usually the arm), and zip tie it all back together. Five minutes and you are back flying. (Pictured is the Turnigy 16-Pole MultiStar 4225-390Kv pancake motor, which has a wide mounting screw pattern).
  • Plug in your ESCs and check the motor rotation direction (STILL with NO PROPELLERS). Once correct, mount your props.
  • Go fly. Depending on how wild you got with the arm lengths you may need to adjust your gains. I have 92 hours on 1855 propellers on my 1.7kg 700mm MTM F450 and my gains are: 180 180 130 150 80 80.
    When things go wrong…
    OK, we all strip screws. It happens & all is not lost. Here are some workarounds I’ve used.
  • Instead of the short screw, use the long one in the stripped hole. If you already stripped a long one….
  • Put a drop of CA in the stripped hole. Let it sit overnight & it will soften and expand the ABS. The next day, insert a new screw. If that doesn’t work,
  • Put a SINGLE drop of acetone in the stripped hole. Be very careful since acetone melts ABS. Let it evaporate and dry overnight. The next day, insert the new screw. If THAT doesn’t work,
  • Fill the hole with epoxy. Let it set. Drill a small hole (about 3mm) and thread in the new screw. If THAT doesn’t work,
  • Drill the hole deeper, about 15mm. Insert a 12-15mm M4 screw & thread it in. If THAT doesn’t work…
  • You are out of luck.

I printed a set of 4 for 16mm. My first attempt was to have it lay flat on the top surface. That resulted in a clamp failure because of the layering. The finished 4 were reset to print on the face of the clamp end, with full support. The legs have to be facing left or right because there is a weird thing with the supports. The ones for the legs only want to point along the Y axis when viewing in layers, no matter which way the mount is pointing on the platform. So I made one today for 12mm (which btw is way too small...11.4mm) for a 13mm tube. So I am trying one in 14mm. I have UM2 using the Olson block 0.6 nozzle, 25% infill, 0.6 shell, 1.2mm bottom and top. I acetone finished them and they look nice. The only cosmetic issue is the infill printed before the shell, so its ribs show through, but that will just make a stronger unit.
Thanks Thing creator.

title: Hard Case for PZ0420 family of FPV Cameras

description.text:
A series of learning events (aka “crashes”) taught me that the probability of destroying an expensive camera in a crash is almost 100%. When I lost my fourth camera after taking off in dew covered grass (a drop or two apparently fried the board) I decided to make a lightweight ABS case that protects the delicate circuitry AND served as a solid mount on my frame. The case is custom fit to the PZ0420 series of cameras with internal reliefs for the large capacitor and three cutouts on the rear for the connection and communication ports. The lens hole fits the standard 2.8mm lens and can be easily enlarged for the larger lenses or the RMRC f1.2 night vision lens. You can zip tie it, CA glue it, or press fit it into most frames with little or no sanding.
In over 18 months of using this (and experiencing several more “learning events”) I have not lost a single camera. Frames...yes. Arms…motors…antennas….yes. Cameras, no.

IMPORTANT
  • After installing this mount, look up your declination here: http://magnetic-declination.com/. I mark my puck with a magic marker so I don’t forget. Use a simple protractor to set the angle. If negative, turn your puck counterclockwise. If positive, clockwise.
  • Before your first flight, calibrate your compass using the DJI instructions. Too easy.
    Some multicopters just don’t offer a good place to mount the GPS puck. My S-500 is one of those and I’ve seen a dozen different ways that guys lash their GPS pucks to these unfriendly frames. The factory answer is to poke a hole in the light plastic dome and zip tie the post to the rear of the shell. Unfortunately, this still allows the antenna to rotate, rendering your calibration useless. As we all know, declination alignment and compass calibration are CRITICAL to stable hovering, alignment, and straight flight. After watching my S-500 “toilet bowl” itself into a tree (again), I decided to come up with a permanent fix.
    • My answer was an ABS adapter attached to the 14mm arm using two zip ties. Between the adapter and arm I applied a layer of sticky tape to keep it vertical. The adapter uses the original 4mm carbon fiber shaft and aluminum puck mount (it is strong and just as light as an ABS one).

title: Skylark GPS Puck Mount (CF Arm Mount)

description.text: I LOVE my Skylark OSDs, but it’s really difficult to find a good way to mount the (expensive) GPS module. This little mount attaches to your multicopter’s arm with two zip ties & allows you to remote the antenna anywhere within cable length – even out under the propellers! In the photo you see the first prototype I used on my endurance quad, mounted adjacent to the frame. The newest version has rounded, aerodynamic edges instead of the square ones shown in the photo.

Like Hamond's cane top in Jurassic park.
Complete with space for mosquito.
Part of my Jurassic Park files I've been working on lately.
I would greatly appreciate if someone could try this method, and let me know if it works or not.

Make in a top and bottom piece, each has a hollow piece in the shape of half of the mosquito.
Recommend making with translucent/transparent orange abs or pla.
Fill the hollow void with black ink, or thinned black paint (starting with the lowest point to avoid air pockets).
After the ink-paint dries, glue the top and bottom together.

author: AmazingDesign

description.text:
This is a customizable pendant of the rhodonea curve and other curves.
This is taken from my curve generator and made into a pendant : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:50249

UPDATE: Now supports up to 5 different types of curves. See updated instructions below for more information. This script will generate a pendant with an artistic rendering of a mathematical curve inside.
It was originally a generator for the Rhodonea curve (Rose).
Here are the equations used for each one of those curves :
Rhodonea curve : x=cos(a/bt)sin(t); y=cos(a/bt)cos(t)
Epicycloid : x=(a+b)cos(t)-bcos(((a/b)+1)t); y=(a+b)sin(t)-bsin(((a/b)+1)t)
Epitrochoid : x=(a+b)cos(t)-ccos(((a/b)+1)t); y=(a+b)sin(t)-csin(((a/b)+1)t)
Hypocycloid : x=(a-b)cos(t)+bcos(((a/b)-1)t); y=(a-b)sin(t)-bsin(((a/b)-1)t)
Hypotrochoid: x=(a-b)cos(t)+ccos(((a/b)-1)t); y=(a-b)sin(t)-csin(((a/b)-1)t)
(See also http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rose_%28mathematics%29 ) You can set the 'a, 'b', and 'c' parameters to affect the look of the pattern (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rose-rhodonea-curve-7x9-chart-improved.svg for example) and chose which pattern type to generate.
The patterns can vary a lot depending on the parameters, even for the same type of curve, so experiment and see what you like. I've created a few remixes that show some of the possibilities. You can define the thickness of the pattern and outer wall as well as the height of pendant The rose radius will set the radius of the pendant.
The epitrochoid, epicycloid, hypotrochoid and hypocycloid patterns may not fit entirely in the outer circle of the pendant, so you can adjust the "Ring Adjustment" property to make them fit completely, or even to make them go beyond the borders if you think it's nicer that way. Experiment, create and enjoy! Note: This is my second attempt at using openscad (the first being http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49590).
This was a lot of work since openscad wasn't made for drawing curves, and it seems I'm the first one to achieve somehting like that.
Thanks for all those who liked the design!

Provincetown MA - Not amazing features like a volcano but it sure gives you an idea of how close to sea-level the Cape is. This is constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle. This is using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL. I hope to release the new software as soon as I get any kinks out.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

title: Snap together Spool Holder - No extra hardware required!

description.text:
I was looking for a spool holder that I could completely 3D print,
was stable and I could easily swap out the Filament rolls. I couldn't
find one already made so I made my own. I didn't want to use
screws or nails, or bearings. So I took a basic concept and
modified it. It took me 4 versions to tweak it just right.
Now I just drop different rolls of filament onto my spool holder.
I even store my filament rolls with extra spools with the
connectors.
The large spindle is 50mm
The small spindle is 30mm
New Smaller Spindle 30mm with thicker walls

Print 2 of the sides, 4 of the edge connectors, 2 supports(with support for overhang) , and 1 spool.
  • Insert the edge connectors into the ends of the Spool (see picture)
  • Insert the supports into the Sides (see picture)
  • Push Spool with edge connectors into Spool Holder Frame

comments.text: Great design, my OneUp wouldn't print all so I cut the sides into 3 pieces, printed and epoxyed and I shortened the spindle and supports to fit my reels. Awesome!
comments.author: roko11

comments.text: Very nice design and just what I need for my dry box.  Thank you!  One comment, I think your support bar stl file has a slight angle to it.  It didn't lay flat on my bed and printed a little support material under one side.  My slicer software (Simplify3D) doesn't change the orientation on import whereas Cura will.

comments.text: I posted up a new Smaller Spindle 30mm.  I measured it in Tinkercad and it has the same wall thickness as the larger spindle.  I super imposed them on each other and they are identical.  The cylinder's inner supports are also the same size as the larger spindle.

comments.text: Thank you for making a 30mm cylinder, but there's a small problem with it.  The walls and internal structure are much thinner on the 30mm cylinder and it makes the pins very loose.  When I mount the spool it sags under its own weight.  If you made the walls and internal supports the same thickness as the larger cylinder it would solve this issue.

description.text:
If anyone wants the raw files let me know or I can add in one that fits your printer better. This is a printhead to fit metal case printer. It is an off brand but some parts are similar to the Medal Prusa. Printer has two horizontal 8mm rods 60mm apart from outside of rods. 52mm on center.
Made for E3D hot ends, one side is shifted to made the two E3D printheads fit on the platform better. Also there are mount holes for a 40 mm fan on the bottom of the print. The channel under the head mount works to direct the airflow nicely. Also I have a center GT2 mount clamp. Printhead_V5 I made a few changes since V4 version, I had some little alignment pieces for the LM8U bearings, but after installing noticed they really didn't need to be in there and just made the print messy. Also tightened up the printhead mounts some, it worked, but caused some print quality issues.

I am using a 0.50 nozzle 40% fill.  3 solid layers.  also just for a perfect start make sure to print a extra perimeter circle around the print.  at least on my Slic3r it goes straight to the screw holes on the bottom after it does the perimeter and want those perfect.

title: The SyKit - by Symantis (Raspberry Pi B+ Case)

description.text:
This is the case for the SyKit!
For more information about what the SyKit actually is check out our awesome community over at symantis.org!
This case is designed to securely house a Raspberry Pi B+. It is sleek, strong and fully modular! A system of magnets allows the top and bottom plates to be snapped on and off as needed, so that multiple Kits can be stacked sky high.
The body is 3D printed, the lids laser cut (although most other forms of steel cutting works too), and the only other element required is 8 small magnets and some glue.
Enjoy!

The body was printed in ABS on a UPrint SE Printer with soluble generated supports at .254mm Z resolution.
Many prototypes were created on an Up Plus printer though, 0.2mm Z resolution, using moderate density supports that yielded positive results.
The outer of body was sanded up to 1000 grit using wet+dry sandpaper followed by 3 coats of matte back spray paint and 2 coats of clear, matte spray lacquer to finish. There are also slots cut out on the top and bottom edges of the case, this is for (optional) silicone rubber to be inserted, to add grip to the plates.
The top and bottom plates are 0.8mm thick magnetized steel that have been laser cut, sanded up to 800 grit and then sealed with 3 coats of clear Briwax.
Finally, the magnets needed measure 6mm x 1mm. They are glued to the 8 posts on the body using super glue (although an epoxy will give a more secure finish). NOTE* The polarities of the magnets need to be carefully aligned to make sure cases will stack properly!
If you have all the ingredients + machinery needed you can crank one of these out, to full completion, in a day. The product has been designed to a professional standard finish, however the sanding/painting is all purely cosmetic and is completely optional.

comments.text: Okay, so I've had the privilege of playing with this thing.  It stacks which is awesome.  It has breathing room for the components and room to wrap ribbon wires internally between stacks (what other case can say that!).  Also, the ventilation is custom designed by Stephen Peck. The RasPi clicks into place. It has ergonomic places to grip and remove the metal.  Basically, if you want to call attention that you have a RasPi on your desk, this is the sleekest design I've ever seen.
comments.author: scottw

title: More polyhedron facet/vertex extensions
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a diverse set of pieces geometrically compatible with and extending http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4934. They are also snap, but not geometrically, compatible with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4899 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4893. I have added spoke versions of squares, pentagons, and hexagons. I have also added version that have both regular and askew polygonal facets. Maybe the straight lines in this version will print more cleanly than the circles in the last version.

Look up templates for polyhedra, and print the corresponding facets. 
I've found that all Archemedian solids can be built from a combination of triangles 1 and 2, square 1, pentagons 1 and 2, and hexagon 1 if you permit flipping inside-out, otherwise both hexagon 1 and 2.
I have not printed and tested this set yet.

description.text: I created this to mount the Auto-Leveling Probe to my Printerbot Simple from 2013.

Print this on a properly calibrated printer and the probe, it's top nut, and the mounting screw will drop right in. Drill a 3mm hold under the extruder motor about 5mm in from the edge, and used a 30mm M3 screw, washers, and a nut to secure the mount in place. Adjust the top nut of the probe until the bottom of the probe is about 1mm from the tip of the extruder nozzle and secure it with the bottom nut.

comments.text: Which sensor are you using?
comments.author: zanahade

comments.text: The sensor is an LJ12A3-4-Z/BY. It's what came with the Printrbot Auto-Leveling Probe kit. It also came with a small PCB with some resistors and a y-adapter to feed it 12 volts.

description.text: The Spoon-Straw is a hybrid of two wonderful objects used to eat and drink. The Spoon-Straw allows you to enjoy your fruit loops and drink your milk without missing a beat. The Spoon-Straw is also great with soup.
Class project. Created on 123D Design.

San Francisco Peaks North of FlagStaff Arizona - This is where you'll find Humphreys Peak which is the highest point in the state of Arizona (12,633 feet). The picture I captured is viewed from the East. This is constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle. This is using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL. I hope to release the new software as soon as I get any kinks out.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

This intriguing mechanism features a constantly rotating input (orange gears) driving an output gear (small white gear) which rotates first in one direction and then in the reverse direction. This is shown (not very well) in this video: http://youtu.be/_0XB8Rn9RqA
Shown much more clearly in this animation: https://youtu.be/jA5n5GlCb5U
which was created in Blender 2.76 using the Physics engine. If you look closely at the animation you will see that the trailing tooth of the central gear, and that of the ring gear have been reduced in height. Unless this is down the physics animation won't work BUT the animation is using a planet gear of 31mm diameter. I've uploaded a planet with an O/D of 29mm which is a bit sloppy in its engagement with the other gears but probably won't require modification of the trailing teeth.
The design was inspired by this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3aobPgGzB-U&list=PLB0IDKx1j2rxVpbfnvui1v5lDLPlaB2gx&spfreload=1 Designed in MOI. Printed in Diamond Age PLA on an Ultimaker 1

The stl files should all have the 'correct' orientation for printing - but check!
I used Brim for the tall upright pieces.
I used Support for the couterbores in the base, but not essential.
I found it necessary to clean all the gear teeth where they had been in contact with the build plate.
After cleaning, I assembled the handle with a soft hammer.
NB The assembly requires 11-off 3mm Button Head Cap Screws with 12mm thread length, though you can probably get by with 10mm long screws.

description.text: A simple kazoo made with laser-cut wood. Video! http://www.flickr.com/photos/ranjit/8472934766/in/set-72157632668657716/

I cut the sides from 1/4" balsa and the top, bottom, and rings from 3mm plywood, but the dimensions aren't very important.
Glue the sides to the bottom, the top to the sides, and the small ring over the top hole.  Cut a piece of crinkly plastic - the cellophane wrapper around a box of teabags is perfect - and use the large ring to hold the plastic over the small ring.  Sing or hum into the fat end of the kazoo, not the skinny end!  If the plastic doesn't buzz with your voice, try making it a bit looser or tighter, or try a different kind of plastic.

SHOCK ABSORBER ASSEMBLER

This is a useful device for transporting liquids, and other items, over short distances. Please note, since this device is gravity assisted, it is only guaranteed to contain it's contents if held with the open end in opposition to the mass generating the strongest gravitational pull at the device. The contents is assumed to have a mass greater than the matter above the open end of the device when it is in proper alignment. It is possible to contain matter that does not meet the above requirement by turning a properly align device 180 degrees around either the X or Y axis.

This script calculates the radius and height based on the required volume, the number of sides, and the golden ratio. If printed on a properly calibrated printer, the device will hold the exact volume requested.

An enclosure for the Arduino that can be laser cut from sheet acrylic. Provides access to the USB port, DC jack, reset button, and pin headers. The case was designed using measurements from an Arduino Uno board. See also: 'Arduino and Ethernet shield enclosure':
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5044 Made at the London Hack Space:
http://london.hackspace.org.uk/

1) Adjust the design to account for your laser cutter kerf: In this design the slots have been shrunk by 0.1mm to account for my laser cutter's kerf and provide a tight fit. However, this will vary depending on your equipment and true thickness of the material.
2) For a good fit you may want to cut a single slot and peg to verify the settings and adjust the design of the slot size accordingly in the DXF or SketchUp file.
3) Cut the design from 3mm acrylic. Slot the pieces together - excluding the lid! 
4) Slide in your Arduino board, USB port first. Secure the board to the base plate with fixings of your choosing. I used some M3 bolts with insulating washers. But you could use PCB stand-offs if you wish - consider the alignment of the boards with the port cut-outs at this point.
5) Attach the top plate and secure with four 30mm M3 bolts. If you are likely to be removing the lid frequently then an elastic band maybe more useful than bolts. Be careful not to over tighten as this may shatter the acrylic.

comments.text:
Hi! This design has a very common problem:
The connectors are too deep below the cover. If you are going to use any shell board, you will get bad contact due to get it far from the arduino board.
I happened the same with another boxes bought trough Aliexpress, and finally I have redesigned the side parts to get 3D printed and to replace the original ones.
Try to change the top of the box to get USB and power connector would pass over it and put lower walls arround, in order to get connectors raising the top cover.

description.text: FAN GUARD 80 MM DIA.

I don't know about you but I have a hard time drawing a straight line and I have to erase a lot while drafting, This nifty gadget will solve all of your 4'' line drawing and erasing needs! This holds a standard poly eraser you can find at any school or hobby store. This design also has a fold out straight edge and a spacer that will hold the eraser up as it gets smaller after use.

I printed this on a Rep2, med quality, 10% infill, no support, raft. after printing I used a wooden tooth pick for the hinge, little bit of sanding. place the spacer in before the eraser. To make it easier to push in the eraser wet it then push it in and let it dry, it should be a tight fit so it will stay in place.

comments.text: two potential issues: (1) stepper motors missed steps potentially due to overheating or jamming on a curled up part of your print or (2) slicer issue, view the G code after slicing to ensure the nozzle path doesn't do something funny.  This can happen if the slicer tries to automatically fix a non manifold object... and doesn't do a very good job.

comments.text:
Hi Mattk007
Printed lovely on my replicator 2. With force (enough to almost draw blood!) I've snapped his legs to the hip, and the head to the body, but how am I meant to get those pins through the body? I've tried printing them at 95% size but a) they still don't fit through the body and b) when I forced one through it's too small to hold the arm?
I'm a bit new to all this but keen to learn - any help appreciated!
comments.author: Mattjd

comments.text:
The problem seems to be the setting on your slicing software. Not sure what you're using, but there should be a setting to adjust the print margin.
One way to test, is create a defined size block and print it, then measure the actual size produced and compare - or else use a calibration piece,
In the interim, I suggest using a drill to drill out the arm holes to a size that the pins can fit through easily and glue into arms.
comments.author: Mattjd

comments.text: You can push the pins from the outside and twist until the go smoothisch. Then push them from the inside and put one layer of tejp on the part that sticks out. GIves a nice smooth movement :)

title: Top Spool Holder for BFB Touch

description.text:
This is simply a support piece that clips to the top of your BFB Touch printer and allows you to mount the normal Spool holder onto it.
Why? Because I find my filament keeps snapping in the long feed tubes from the the bottom, and this lets you use a very short feed tube. Update: I have added a slightly longer version to accomodate larger spools.

Print out part. ( 60% or more fill for stiffness )
Un-screw spool holder from base of printer and re-mount in holder.
Clip on to top rail of printer - I find works best at the back.
(Works fine with the lid on too )
Place spool on holder .
Cut a short section of feed-tube to help guide the filament.
Feed the filament and enjoy !

title: J-HEAD securer with 40mm fan. Wade's Extruder compatible.

description.text:
This is a J-HEAD securer, with a 4cm fan support. The whole thing was made easy to assemble and remove. You'll need 30mm 3M for securing the j-head and of course the screw for the fan.
You also need to glue together the two parts of the fan.
Before print this thing make sure that the resistance of the extruder will not be in the way! :)
You may want to print the main part with 100% fill, obtaining a stronger holder.
It's not perfect, but I don't have the time to make it better, sorry!
Inspired from the Clausevic "J-Head plate mounting" - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:381348

Print, put the J-HEAD in the Holder, secure with the Securer and mount it under the Wades with 4M screw.
Glue the parts of the fan and then You can attach the rest with some pressure.

author: nemwiper

description.text: A printed flower, made for my Wife.

Print 2 bud half's and a stem and press/glue together.
I have tested this with Cura Daid on a RepRapPro printed at 0.1 layer height, 20% infill with 3 perimeters with Faberdashery PLA.  I had to slow the print way down on the final few layers to get the rim to finish correctly so make sure your minimum layer time is like 10 seconds.

author: EchoSeven

description.text:
This is an idea I've been working on in my head for several months and dozens of revisions. I finally decided to get something into the computer and post it, and gave myself 24 hours to do it. This is a very small extruder block (it should be smaller than Brut) that has a spring-tensioned bearing idler like Wade's and a single tightening screw like the Mk5 Plastruder. It is designed to be used with a planetary gear stepper like this one, and Mk5 drive gear with the hole drilled out to 8mm to fit the gearbox shaft. It uses two M3x35mm screws, two M4x50mm screws, one M8 bolt or rod about 35mm long, one 608 bearing, and a couple of nuts and washers to match these. One end is meant to hold a nut screwed onto a PTFE tube (which could be a bowden cable, or if it runs the other direction, it could just be a feed tube) and the other end is meant to accept a groove-mount insulator, so the same block can be used as a bowden or carriage-mounted extruder with no extra mountings. In the included picture, the transparent parts are all vitamins. The cylinder at the bottom is the planetary gearbox, with the stepper (not pictured) on the other end. The Mk5 gear rendered yellow for some reason. The wide cylinder in front of it is the 608 idler. The M4 screw with the spring around it is for tensioning, and the other M4 (goes through the hole at the top to hold the other end of the M8 rod and act as a pivot. I tried to print one to try it out, but my x-axis is acting up again. To do:
Print one and test it to see what needs to be added to this list.
Figure out how to lock in the bowden nut and insulator.
Find some way of mounting it to a carriage The mounting should probably attach to the motor rather than the extruder, as it is pretty far from the motor's center of mass, but the spacer piece could also be redesigned for this function.
Make it parametric.
Design a printable gearbox to optionally replace the printed one (one of my first ideas, seeing that beak90 beat me to designing one was one of the things that made me get off my ass and start working on this).
See if I can make the design work with a DC gearmotor.

Stainless steel is probably a better material than bronze, but I am very impressed with the quality of this part. The worm gear teeth are shaper than the MK5's and it looks like it will grip better.

title: Sony Xperia Z1 Compact Docking Station

description.text:
A simple stand for the Xperia Z1 Compact, inspired by the original docking station DK-32.
In combination with a standard magnetic USB charging cable it becomes a docking station.
I added some rubber feet to mine for stability.
Have fun! More Pictures follow..

Just print with at least 20 % filling, otherwise it will be a little to light and may not stand stable.
I printed mine with a shell thickness of 1.2 mm and a layer height of 0.1 mm, which took about 2 h.
I recommend printing it bottom up, so the top surface looks nice and clean and also the cable canal is smooth.

author: y2kproblem

description.text:
Dell Optiplex GX520 GX620 745 755 755 760 hard drive caddy tray. This is my first creation i  do not have a printer to print and test it yet.   
3/22/2014 UPDATE after wasting plastic trying to clone this caddy i designed tabs that accomplish the same function without using as much plastic and no locking mechanism. This new design relies on slightly oversized parts to create enough friction to keep the hard drive from moving. Plus it's universal Just make sure the thicker tab resets under the drive. Providing a spacer and friction to keep the drive in place when slid into the bay.
